sect1.title: Overview
sect1.para: EPL date-time methods work on date-time values to perform common tasks such as adding or subtracting time periods, setting or rounding calendar fields and querying fields.

Date-time methods operate on any expression or event property that returns either a long-type millisecond value, a java.util.Calendar or java.util.Date. Consider the built-in single-row function current_timestamp for use with date-time methods.
The below table summarizes the built-in date-time methods available:

sect2.title: Syntax
sect2.para: The syntax for date-time methods is the same syntax as for any chained invocation:

Following the input_val input value is the . (dot) operator and the datetime_method_name date-time method name. It follows in parenthesis a comma-separated list of method parameter expressions. Additional date-time methods can be chained thereafter.

The input value can be any expression or event property that returns a value of type long or java.util.Calendar or java.util.Date. If the input value is a long-type millisecond value, the output is also a long-type millisecond value. If the input is a Calendar-type value the output is also a Calendar-type value. If the input is a Date-type value the output is also a Date-type value. If the input value is null, the expression result is also null.
The following example EPL statement employs the withTime date-time method. This example returns the current engine time with the time-part set to 1 am:
sect2.programlisting: select current_timestamp.withTime(1, 0, 0, 0) as time1am from MyEvent
sect2.para: As date-time methods can be chained, this EPL is equivalent:
sect2.programlisting: select current_timestamp.set('hour', 1).set('min', 0).set('sec', 0).set('msec', 0) as time1am from MyEvent
sect2.para: The statement above outputs in field time1am a long-type millisecond-value reflecting 1am on the same date as engine time. Since the input value is provided by the built-in current_timestamp function which returns current engine date as a long-type millisecond value the output is also a long-type millisecond value.
You may apply a date-time method to an event property.

Assume that the RFIDEvent event type has a Date-type property by name timeTaken. The following query rounds each time-taken value down to the nearest minute and outputs a Date-type value in column timeTakenRounded:
sect2.programlisting: select timeTaken.roundFloor('min') as timeTakenRounded from RFIDEvent
sect2.para: For comparing date-time values we recommend comparing millisecond values using the between or in ranges and inverted ranges or relational operators (> , <, >=, <=).
From a performance perspective, the date-time method evaluation ensures that for each unique chain of date-time methods only a single calendar objects is copied or created when necessary.

sect2.title: Format
sect2.para: The format date-time method formats the date-time returning a string.
The method takes no parameters. It returns the date-time value formatted using the default locale format obtained from new SimpleDateFormat().
The example below outputs the time-taken property value of the RFID event:
sect2.programlisting: select timeTaken.format() as timeTakenStr from RFIDEvent

sect2.title: Get (By Field)
sect2.para: The get date-time method returns the value of the given date-time value field.
The method takes a single string-constant field name as parameter. Please see for a list of recognized keywords (not case-sensitive).

The method returns the numeric value of the field within the date-time value. The value returned adheres to Calendar-class semantics: For example, the value for month starts at zero and has a maximum of 11.
The example below outputs the month value of the time-taken property value of the RFID event:
sect2.programlisting: select timeTaken.get('month') as timeTakenMonth from RFIDEvent

sect2.title: Get (By Name)
sect2.para: The following list of getter-methods are available: getMillisOfSecond(), getSecondOfMinute(), getMinuteOfHour(), getHourOfDay(), getDayOfWeek(), getDayOfMonth(), getDayOfYear(), getWeekYear(), getMonthOfYear(), getYear() and getEra().

All get-methods take no parameter and return the numeric value of the field within the date-time value. The value returned adheres to Calendar-class semantics: For example, the value for month starts at zero and has a maximum of 11.
The example below outputs the month value of the time-taken property value of the RFID event:
sect2.programlisting: select timeTaken.getMonthOfYear() as timeTakenMonth from RFIDEvent

sect2.title: Minus
sect2.para: The minus date-time method returns a date-time with the specified duration taken away.
The method has two versions: The first version takes the duration as a long-type millisecond value. The second version takes the duration as a time-period expression, see .
The example below demonstrates the time-period parameter to subtract two minutes from the time-taken property value of the RFID event:
sect2.programlisting: select timeTaken.minus(2 minutes) as timeTakenMinus2Min from RFIDEvent
sect2.para: The next example is equivalent but passes a millisecond-value instead:
sect2.programlisting: select timeTaken.minus(2*60*1000) as timeTakenMinus2Min from RFIDEvent

sect2.title: Plus
sect2.para: The plus date-time method returns a date-time with the specified duration added.
The method has two versions: The first version takes the duration as a long-type millisecond value. The second version takes the duration as a time-period expression, see .
The next example adds two minutes to the time-taken property value of the RFID event:
sect2.programlisting: select timeTaken.plus(2 minutes) as timeTakenPlus2Min from RFIDEvent
sect2.para: The next example is equivalent but passes a millisecond-value instead:
sect2.programlisting: select timeTaken.plus(2*60*1000) as timeTakenPlus2Min from RFIDEvent

sect2.title: RoundCeiling
sect2.para: The roundCeiling date-time method rounds to the highest whole unit of the date-time field.
The method takes a single string-constant field name as parameter. Please see for a list of recognized keywords (not case-sensitive).
The next example rounds-to-ceiling the minutes of the time-taken property value of the RFID event:
sect2.programlisting: select timeTaken.roundCeiling('min') as timeTakenRounded from RFIDEvent
sect2.para: If the input time is 2002-05-30 09:01:23.050, for example, the output is 2002-05-30 09:02:00.000 (example timestamps are in format yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss.SSS).

sect2.title: RoundFloor
sect2.para: The roundFloor date-time method rounds to the lowest whole unit of the date-time field.
The method takes a single string-constant field name as parameter. Please see for a list of recognized keywords (not case-sensitive).
The next example rounds-to-floor the minutes of the time-taken property value of the RFID event:
sect2.programlisting: select timeTaken.roundFloor('min') as timeTakenRounded from RFIDEvent
sect2.para: If the input time is 2002-05-30 09:01:23.050, for example, the output is 2002-05-30 09:01:00.000 (example timestamps are in format yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss.SSS).

sect2.title: RoundHalf
sect2.para: The roundFloor date-time method rounds to the nearest whole unit of the date-time field.
The method takes a single string-constant field name as parameter. Please see for a list of recognized keywords (not case-sensitive).
The next example rounds the minutes of the time-taken property value of the RFID event:
sect2.programlisting: select timeTaken.roundHalf('min') as timeTakenRounded from RFIDEvent

sect2.title: Set (By Field)
sect2.para: The set date-time method returns a date-time with the specified field set to the value returned by an expression.
The method takes a string-constant field name and an expression returning an integer-value as parameters. Please see for a list of recognized keywords (not case-sensitive).

The method returns the new date-time value with the field set to the provided value. Note that value adheres to Calendar-class semantics: For example, the value for month starts at zero and has a maximum of 11.
The example below outputs the time-taken with the value for month set to April:
sect2.programlisting: select timeTaken.set('month', 3) as timeTakenMonth from RFIDEvent

sect2.title: WithDate
sect2.para: The withDate date-time method returns a date-time with the specified date, retaining the time fields.
The method takes three expressions as parameters: An expression for year, month and day.

The method returns the new date-time value with the date fields set to the provided values. For expressions returning null the method ignores the field for which null is returned. Note the Calendar-class semantics: For example, the value for month starts at zero and has a maximum of 11.
The example below outputs the time-taken with the date set to May 30, 2002:
sect2.programlisting: select timeTaken.withDate(2002, 4, 30) as timeTakenDated from RFIDEvent

sect2.title: WithMax
sect2.para: The withMax date-time method returns a date-time with the field set to the maximum value for the field.
The method takes a string-constant field name as parameter. Please see for a list of recognized keywords (not case-sensitive).
The method returns the new date-time value with the specific date field set to the maximum value.
The example below outputs the time-taken property value with the second-part as 59 seconds:
sect2.programlisting: select timeTaken.withMax('sec') as timeTakenMaxSec from RFIDEvent

sect2.title: WithMin
sect2.para: The withMin date-time method returns a date-time with the field set to the minimum value for the field.
The method takes a string-constant field name as parameter. Please see for a list of recognized keywords (not case-sensitive).
The method returns the new date-time value with the specific date field set to the minimum value.
The example below outputs the time-taken property value with the second-part as 0 seconds:
sect2.programlisting: select timeTaken.withMin('sec') as timeTakenMaxSec from RFIDEvent

sect2.title: WithTime
sect2.para: The withTime date-time method returns a date-time with the specified time, retaining the date fields.
The method takes four expressions as parameters: An expression for hour, minute, second and millisecond.
The method returns the new date-time value with the time fields set to the provided values. For expressions returning null the method ignores the field for which null is returned.
The example below outputs the time-taken with the time set to 9am:
sect2.programlisting: select timeTaken.withTime(9, 0, 0, 0) as timeTakenDated from RFIDEvent

sect2.title: ToCalendar
sect2.para: The toCalendar date-time method returns the Calendar object for this date-time value.
The method takes no parameters.
The example below outputs the time-taken as a Calendar object:
sect2.programlisting: select timeTaken.toCalendar() as timeTakenCal from RFIDEvent

sect2.title: ToDate
sect2.para: The toDate date-time method returns the Date object for this date-time value.
The method takes no parameters.
The example below outputs the time-taken as a Date object:
sect2.programlisting: select timeTaken.toDate() as timeTakenDate from RFIDEvent

sect2.title: ToMillisec
sect2.para: The toMillisec date-time method returns the long-typed millisecond value for this date-time value.
The method takes no parameters.
The example below outputs the time-taken as a long-typed millisecond value:
sect2.programlisting: select timeTaken.toMillisec() as timeTakenLong from RFIDEvent
